Award.AwardTitle: Effect of Hydrogen on the Sulfur-rich Martian Core
Award.AbstractNarration: Studies of Mars over the past twenty years have determined that early in its history the climate was warm enough for water to flow on its surface. Liquid water is not found on the surface of Mars today, because the surface is too cold and the atmosphere too thin. The cause of this change might be the loss of the planet’s global magnetic field, allowing the solar radiation to strip the atmosphere. This would imply a major change took place in the planet’s core, shutting off the dynamo responsible for the magnetic field. The role of hydrogen in the dynamics and structure of the Martian core is poorly understood. Hydrogen is known to form alloys with metallic iron at high pressure. This program will conduct a systematic study of the phase relations of such alloys at the pressure and temperature conditions expected for the Martian core. This research will provide Arizona State University undergraduate students with comprehensive research experiences. Teaching modules motivated by this research will be implemented in coding and data analysis courses at ASU. <br/><br/>The primary goal of this project is to advance the understanding of the dynamics and structure of the Martian core by conducting experiments to measure the melting behavior and sub-solidus phase relations in Fe-S-H systems at pressures of 25-40 Gigapascals (GPs) expected to exist at the Martian core. To achieve this goal a series of high-pressure, high temperature experiments will be conducted for: (1) possible miscibility (or solubility) gaps in Fe-S-H systems at high pressure and high temperature conditions relevant to the Martian core, (2) the effects of hydrogen on the melting temperature of sulfide alloys and (3) sub-solidus phase relations in Fe-S-H systems at high pressures and high temperatures.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Mars, now uninhabitable, was once potentially habitable. The loss of its global magnetic field early in its history, however, marked a turning point towards its current state. Understanding why Mars's magnetic field vanished is crucial, as such a field is generated in a planet's core and is essential for protecting its atmosphere—and any potential life—from harsh solar winds. The InSight mission has uncovered that Mars's iron-rich core contains a large amount of light elements, possibly more so than Earth's core. This discovery underscores the influence of these elements on the core's past. Our research, funded by this grant, has focused on the roles of sulfur and hydrogen in Mars's core. We've conducted experiments simulating the high-pressure conditions of the core. Our findings reveal that hydrogen destabilizes the Fe3S alloy—a compound once thought to be a core component—resulting in the formation of distinct iron-sulfur and iron-hydrogen alloys. This suggests that the interplay of sulfur and hydrogen was critical in Mars's core evolution, offering new insights on important chemical processes for the magnetic history of Mars’s core.

Broader Impact: The enigma of Mars's magnetic field is not just a scientific challenge; it is a question that touches on the very possibility of life on other planets. Our quest to decode the chemical and physical processes within Mars's core extends beyond academic curiosity; it has the potential to illuminate the conditions necessary for planetary habitability. This project has also made significant contributions to the scientific community and education. It has provided essential career development for three postdoctoral researchers and a doctoral candidate, fostering the next generation of scientists. Our commitment to open science is reflected in the development and sharing of data analysis tools, which have been made freely available. These tools are not only resources for researchers but also serve as educational material for university-level STEM programs, enhancing the learning experience and promoting scientific literacy. Through this grant, we are not only deciphering the mysteries of a distant world but also equipping young minds with the knowledge and skills to continue this exploration.
